title: Unsupervised Learning of Data Linking Configuration
segmentation: Good afternoon and.
Today I'm going to talk about the link discovery problem.

It's a well known problem which existed and was studied in the database community for a long time as record linkage and it remains very important for linked data as well, especially as so many new datasets are being published and have to be interlinked.
The goal is simple to find out which two individuals from different datasets actually refer to the same real world.
Entity.
And create a link between such instances.
And the challenges here are many.
First three schema heterogeneity, different representation formats for data values, incorrect and missing data values and so on.
A common way of addressing this is this problem is to.
For instance, matching over individuals from 2 datasets.
We identify relevant pairs of properties.
We compare them with value similarity functions, and then we aggregate these into one common similarity which is compared against a cutoff threshold.
This is a decision rule, for instance, for standard format of a decision rule.

For instance matching, of course, because there are so many parameters to set, like different similarity functions, choosing relevant attribute pairs, aggregation functions, values of weights and threshold expert knowledge is often required here.
For example, knowing that Jaro Winkler similarity generally works better for personal names but not for document titles.

Since there is no straightforward guidance on this and it's often a trial and error procedure, machine learning algorithms provide promising way of adapting this decision rule to a specific domain and specific datasets.
We're dealing with the obvious.
So drawback is the training data is required.
To do so.

Zerrissen ongoing research effort to reduce the amount of training data involved, in particular by using active learning techniques or to utilize existing link data repositories available on the web as training data.
However, this only works for some datasets and ontologies.
So the logical continuation would be to raise a question.
Can we actually do it without having labeled training data?
And if yes, to which extent?
So in order to address this.
Let's first have a look what is a good decision rule, for instance matching and what is it supposed to do?
It has to minimize defects.
To avoid producing spurious mappings between individuals which are really distinct.
And to maximize output, to discover as many actually correct through positive mappings as possible.
End this.
Parties are commonly evaluated using standard measures precision, which evaluates the amount of defects and recall which does it for.
Which estimates the percentage of correct mappings actually identified, and these commonly combined into an F measure.
Which depends on the parameter beta, which specifies relative importance of recall over precision.
Of course, calculating these evaluation measures requires knowing gold standard mappings in advance, and if we had those, we wouldn't need to solve the link discovery problem.
However, if we look at the features of the actual.
They publish datasets on the web.
We can notice that some of them have certain features which are helpful when we.
Try to evaluate the mappings to such produced towards such datasets.
Some repositories are considered as reference once and often serve as linking hubs that cause they are considered reliable.
And comprehensive have a good coverage of data on their chosen topic such as DB Pedia for example for generic domain, geonames for geographic data, or could be Explorer for publications and so on.
So when linking to such repositories, we can make several assump.
First, we expect that your eyes, coined by this repository producers serve as unique identifiers, which means that there is almost no internal duplicates in such datasets.
And therefore all mappings towards such datasets should be one to one.
Second, there comprehensive, which means that we expect that when we link our datasets to such a repository, there should be a substantial overlap between repositories.
And there will be a sufficient number of actually identical instances.
And finally, which is a generic one?
Is that a good similarity function value is about 1.
Four should be about 1.
Four actually identical individuals, while close to 04 distinct ones.
So for example, if we have a.
Decisional rule which produces a set of mappings between two repositories.
And we notice that it cannot distinguish between several instances.
So, for example, it produces 2 links from one George Bush instance.
We immediately know that one of these links is incorrect.
We don't know which one.
We don't know if there is at least one correct, but we know that there is at least one error.
And if we see another output of a different decision rule which only produces one to one mappings, we expect it to be of a better quality.
And if we have a third decision rule which doesn't introduce any one too many mappings.
But is able to discover more.
Actual links between instances.
We expect that this one works even better.
So we formalize these heuristics into a fitness function.
So the first measure which we use is called pseudo precision and which is defined as the ratio of number of individuals which have at least one link to the set of all mappings from these individuals.
So the higher is the proportion of 1 to one links, the greater is pseudo precision value.
The second one we call pseudo recall, and it's defined as again the proportion ratio of individuals which have at least one link produced by our.
Unknown decision rule divided by the size of the smaller data set, so the more links arrow is able to produce the better.
And we combine these two measures into a standard in the standard way as an F measure, and we call it absurd F measure.
However, he is a tricky set since the pseudo Rico is often less should be often less than one 'cause it's not always the case at all.
Individuals from a data set should be mapped to another one.
Therefore we deal with this by choosing a low value of a parameter beta so that pseudo recall is only used to discriminate between decision rules, which have almost similar precision.
And identifying these fitness function, we implement it to guide a genetic.
Freedom to evolve an initial population of candidate decision rules.
First we initialize pool of decision rules with random parameters.
Then we apply these rules to both datasets.
We evaluate the links produced by this decision rules.
Using our pseudo F measure fitness function.
And we use these results to apply standard operators of a genetic algorithm.
Last, like crossover, mutation, elitist selection, and updates the pool of candidate solutions.
After repeating this procedure several iterations, we identify the decision rule which has best.
Fitness value according to our absolute F measure and return it as a result.
So each decision rule is encoded as a vector of parameters, which includes the aggregation.
Function The weights of each attribute comparison.
The similarity function applied to each pair of properties and threshold.
And this one is called the Geno type.
The mutation operator.
Applied to such a Geno type takes randomly one parameter and tweaks it, either by replacing it with another random value or by adding or subtracting certain constant if it's a numeric parameter.
The second operator, which is a crossover, takes as input to G Note.
Types which you call parents and produces two genotypes, called children, each of which takes the value of one of its parameters randomly from each of the parent.
So we implemented these.
Magic algorithm as part of our system for data interlinking called nofas.
Each first performs blocking by identifying pairs of individuals which are likely to be similar, and which potentially can be matching instances, then passes this.
Initial set of candidate mappings to the genetic algorithm after running the genetic algorithm, we determine the optimal decision rule.
We apply it to the to our datasets and filter resulting mappings by enforcing against one to one.
Restriction rule so.
After we implemented it, we tested it on.
Several datasets.
This is an example behavior of a fitness function so we can see that.
During the first iterations there is.
The algorithm identifies the most.
Informative pairs of attributes, so two curves below as the average sale of measure and the average actual F measure among instances in the population.
And the two cars on the top as a correspondingly the best absurd or F measure and best actual F1 measure in the population.
So first the first couple of iterations algorithm usually identifies the most discriminative properties.
After several iterations, it learns how to combine them and spends the rest of iterations by tweaking the.
Weights and threshold parameters in general.
20 iterations was sufficient for convergence in all our experiments.
To check the effect of.
Changing other genetic algorithm parameters we where is the population size.
Competitive and we compared our unsupervised genetic algorithm with the supervised version where supervised version was an ideal case where we use the actual F measure as a fitness function.
So assuming we have all.
Correct mappings known in advance and the task of the genetic algorithm.
In this case it just to try to generalize from it.
As we can see, choosing the low.
Value for the population size doesn't allow for the well off and doesn't allow for the genetic for the unsupervised version to perform well like.
In this case, there is a large gap.
Then with increasing the this population size parameter we can see that the gap diminishes on one of the datasets.
We achieve almost the same result.
Between the supervised and unsupervised case.
And also that further increase in these population size doesn't produce much gain in performance.
ENT wherein crossover and mutation rate didn't result in significant difference in performance by the time when the algorithm reaches 20s generation.
Is the next step we performed.
Comparative evaluation of our.
Algorithm by applying it to two benchmarks.
The first one was.
Using the person restaurant benchmark from the ontology Alignment Evaluation Initiative 2010.
And we compared the actual F1 measure obtained by our unsupervised learning algorithm with those produced by other tools.
And we found that in two cases out of four it outperformed all others.
In one case, it achieved the same highest performance and in one case it scored the 2nd.
Send applied to a more large scale benchmark from the ontology Alignment Evaluation 2011.
Where is the benchmark was taken from Link?
Data cloud and included links between New York Times data and DB Pedia Freebase and Geonames.
Again, we found out that in forecast in four cases out of seven test cases, our unsupervised algorithm was able to outperform the others and overall it achieved the same.
Average half measure as the second.
As the top performing algorithm from the others.

To be addressed whenever we deal with a genetic algorithm is scalability becausw.

Choosing that very low sample results in the algorithm not being sufficiently robust.
Sometimes it is able to converge on a meaningful function, sometimes it doesn't.

There is almost no well it reaches its optimal performance.
In this case, it was at the sample size 100 and the first again.
